title: Miles of Heartache
lyrics:
(Verse 1)
Sunrise paints the cotton fields, another day begins
But the light don't shine so bright no more, since you left for distant lands
Said you'd write, said you'd call, promised you'd always be near
But the miles stretched out between us, fueled by doubt and fear.
(Chorus)
Miles of heartache, winding roads of sorrow,
Every mile a memory, of a love we couldn't borrow
From the future, from the years, from a life we'd planned to share
Now just miles of heartache, and a love beyond repair.
(Verse 2)
Remember dancin' in the moonlight, beneath the summer sky?
Your laughter echoed in the fields, a song that made me fly.
We built a dream on promises, as solid as the ground
But the city lights and city life, tore our love unbound.
(Chorus)
Miles of heartache, winding roads of sorrow,
Every mile a memory, of a love we couldn't borrow
From the future, from the years, from a life we'd planned to share
Now just miles of heartache, and a love beyond repair.
(Bridge)
I keep your picture by my bed, a faded photograph
A constant reminder of the love, that distance stole, alas.
Maybe someday I'll forget, the pain that cuts so deep
But until then, these miles of heartache, are the only truth I keep.
(Chorus)
Miles of heartache, winding roads of sorrow,
Every mile a memory, of a love we couldn't borrow
From the future, from the years, from a life we'd planned to share
Now just miles of heartache, and a love beyond repair.
(Outro)
Miles… miles of heartache… yeah… gone…
sounds_like_acoustic: This song sounds like a lost Hank Williams track, with a touch of George Jones's melancholic vocals and Merle Haggard's storytelling ability. The instrumentation would be sparse but effective: a mournful steel guitar weeping throughout, a steady rhythm guitar providing a simple, heartbroken pulse, a walking bassline, and subtle fiddle flourishes in the chorus. The drums would be restrained, keeping the focus on the vocals and the instruments' emotional delivery. The overall feel is raw, honest, and steeped in the classic country traditions of heartbreak and longing.
